sect1.title: Tutorials
sect1.para: This section contains tutorials demonstrating the use of JSure and its program annotations to assure the correct use of locks in concurrent Java programs. The first two tutorials use small closed-world examples to demonstrate annotating code and using JSure, starting with no annotations at all. The remaining turorials begin with a partially annotated program, and demonstrate more sophisticated concepts such as support for java.util.concurrent reader–writer locks.

figure.title: Menu item to install tutorial projects into your workspace

sect1.para: These tutorials assume that you have installed JSure. If you see a JSure menu item on your Eclipse main menu than you can assume it has been installed properly. To follow along with the tutorials you will also need to add the tutorial projects to your workspace. From the Eclipse main menu, choose JSureRun JSure Tutorials and add the projects to your workspace as displayed in and .

note.title: Do not use the Uniqueness Verifying Analysis
note.para: Please ensure that Use Uniqueness Verifying Analysis is not checked as shown in . This analysis is not recommended for use in the current release and is not used in the following tutorials. The tool default is that it is not checked, but please double-check this setting before you start working through a tutorial.

figure.title: Adding tutorial projects to your workspace

note.title: Several of the imported projects will not compile in Eclipse
note.para: The JSureTutorial_PlanetBaron and JSureTutorial_EffectiveEffects projects will not compile without errors until you add the Promises Library JAR into the build path of each project. A few of the tutorial projects, such as JSureTutorial_ThreadSafeAndImmutable, compile without errors because no annotations have been placed into the projects yet.

sect1.para:
Next, we need to add the SureLogic annotation types in the package com.surelogic to each tutorial project's class path. This is most easily done by allowing JSure to do it for us:
Select JSureAdd/Update Promises Library in Project... from the Eclipse menu.
Press Select All in the dialog which appears. If you did not start with an empty Eclipse workspace, you may want to uncheck any of your own projects that appear in this dialog.
Then press OK to add the promises JAR to each project's classpath.
All the tutorial projects should now compile in your Eclipse workspace without errors.
